body:
Old Anthony Rockwall, retired manufacturer and proprietor of Rockwallâs
Eureka Soap, looked out the library window of his Fifth Avenue mansion and
grinned. His neighbour to the rightâthe aristocratic clubman, G. Van
Schuylight Suffolk-Jonesâcame out to his waiting motor-car, wrinkling a
contumelious nostril, as usual, at the Italian renaissance sculpture of the
soap palaceâs front elevation.


âStuck-up old statuette of nothing doing!â commented the ex-Soap
King. âThe Eden Museeâll get that old frozen Nesselrode yet if he
donât watch out. Iâll have this house painted red, white, and blue
next summer and see if thatâll make his Dutch nose turn up any
higher.â


And then Anthony Rockwall, who never cared for bells, went to the door of his
library and shouted âMike!â in the same voice that had once chipped
off pieces of the welkin on the Kansas prairies.


âTell my son,â said Anthony to the answering menial, âto come
in here before he leaves the house.â


When young Rockwall entered the library the old man laid aside his newspaper,
looked at him with a kindly grimness on his big, smooth, ruddy countenance,
rumpled his mop of white hair with one hand and rattled the keys in his pocket
with the other.


âRichard,â said Anthony Rockwall, âwhat do you pay for the
soap that you use?â


Richard, only six months home from college, was startled a little. He had not
yet taken the measure of this sire of his, who was as full of unexpectednesses
as a girl at her first party.


âSix dollars a dozen, I think, dad.â


âAnd your clothes?â


âI suppose about sixty dollars, as a rule.â


âYouâre a gentleman,â said Anthony, decidedly.
âIâve heard of these young bloods spending $24 a dozen for soap,
and going over the hundred mark for clothes. Youâve got as much money to
waste as any of âem, and yet you stick to whatâs decent and
moderate. Now I use the old Eurekaânot only for sentiment, but itâs
the purest soap made. Whenever you pay more than 10 cents a cake for soap you
buy bad perfumes and labels. But 50 cents is doing very well for a young man in
your generation, position and condition. As I said, youâre a gentleman.
They say it takes three generations to make one. Theyâre off.
Moneyâll do it as slick as soap grease. Itâs made you one. By
hokey! itâs almost made one of me. Iâm nearly as impolite and
disagreeable and ill-mannered as these two old Knickerbocker gents on each side
of me that canât sleep of nights because I bought in between
âem.â


âThere are some things that money canât accomplish,â remarked
young Rockwall, rather gloomily.


âNow, donât say that,â said old Anthony, shocked. âI
bet my money on money every time. Iâve been through the encyclopaedia
down to Y looking for something you canât buy with it; and I expect to
have to take up the appendix next week. Iâm for money against the field.
Tell me something money wonât buy.â


âFor one thing,â answered Richard, rankling a little, âit
wonât buy one into the exclusive circles of society.â


âOho! wonât it?â thundered the champion of the root of evil.
âYou tell me where your exclusive circles would be if the first Astor
hadnât had the money to pay for his steerage passage over?â


Richard sighed.


âAnd thatâs what I was coming to,â said the old man, less
boisterously. âThatâs why I asked you to come in. Thereâs
something going wrong with you, boy. Iâve been noticing it for two weeks.
Out with it. I guess I could lay my hands on eleven millions within twenty-four
hours, besides the real estate. If itâs your liver, thereâs the
Rambler down in the bay, coaled, and ready to steam down to the Bahamas
in two days.â


âNot a bad guess, dad; you havenât missed it far.â


âAh,â said Anthony, keenly; âwhatâs her name?â


Richard began to walk up and down the library floor. There was enough
comradeship and sympathy in this crude old father of his to draw his
confidence.


âWhy donât you ask her?â demanded old Anthony.
âSheâll jump at you. Youâve got the money and the looks, and
youâre a decent boy. Your hands are clean. Youâve got no Eureka
soap on âem. Youâve been to college, but sheâll overlook
that.â


âI havenât had a chance,â said Richard.


âMake one,â said Anthony. âTake her for a walk in the park,
or a straw ride, or walk home with her from church. Chance! Pshaw!â


âYou donât know the social mill, dad. Sheâs part of the
stream that turns it. Every hour and minute of her time is arranged for days in
advance. I must have that girl, dad, or this town is a blackjack swamp
forevermore. And I canât write itâI canât do that.â


âTut!â said the old man. âDo you mean to tell me that with
all the money Iâve got you canât get an hour or two of a
girlâs time for yourself?â


âIâve put it off too late. Sheâs going to sail for Europe at
noon day after to-morrow for a two yearsâ stay. Iâm to see her
alone to-morrow evening for a few minutes. Sheâs at Larchmont now at her
auntâs. I canât go there. But Iâm allowed to meet her with a
cab at the Grand Central Station to-morrow evening at the 8.30 train. We drive
down Broadway to Wallackâs at a gallop, where her mother and a box party
will be waiting for us in the lobby. Do you think she would listen to a
declaration from me during that six or eight minutes under those circumstances?
No. And what chance would I have in the theatre or afterward? None. No, dad,
this is one tangle that your money canât unravel. We canât buy one
minute of time with cash; if we could, rich people would live longer.
Thereâs no hope of getting a talk with Miss Lantry before she
sails.â


âAll right, Richard, my boy,â said old Anthony, cheerfully.
âYou may run along down to your club now. Iâm glad it ainât
your liver. But donât forget to burn a few punk sticks in the joss house
to the great god Mazuma from time to time. You say money wonât buy time?
Well, of course, you canât order eternity wrapped up and delivered at
your residence for a price, but Iâve seen Father Time get pretty bad
stone bruises on his heels when he walked through the gold diggings.â


That night came Aunt Ellen, gentle, sentimental, wrinkled, sighing, oppressed
by wealth, in to Brother Anthony at his evening paper, and began discourse on
the subject of loversâ woes.


âHe told me all about it,â said brother Anthony, yawning. âI
told him my bank account was at his service. And then he began to knock money.
Said money couldnât help. Said the rules of society couldnât be
bucked for a yard by a team of ten-millionaires.â


âOh, Anthony,â sighed Aunt Ellen, âI wish you would not think
so much of money. Wealth is nothing where a true affection is concerned. Love
is all-powerful. If he only had spoken earlier! She could not have refused our
Richard. But now I fear it is too late. He will have no opportunity to address
her. All your gold cannot bring happiness to your son.â


At eight oâclock the next evening Aunt Ellen took a quaint old gold ring
from a moth-eaten case and gave it to Richard.


âWear it to-night, nephew,â she begged. âYour mother gave it
to me. Good luck in love she said it brought. She asked me to give it to you
when you had found the one you loved.â


Young Rockwall took the ring reverently and tried it on his smallest finger. It
slipped as far as the second joint and stopped. He took it off and stuffed it
into his vest pocket, after the manner of man. And then he âphoned for
his cab.


At the station he captured Miss Lantry out of the gadding mob at eight
thirty-two.


âWe mustnât keep mamma and the others waiting,â said she.


âTo Wallackâs Theatre as fast as you can drive!â said Richard
loyally.


They whirled up Forty-second to Broadway, and then down the white-starred lane
that leads from the soft meadows of sunset to the rocky hills of morning.


At Thirty-fourth Street young Richard quickly thrust up the trap and ordered
the cabman to stop.


âIâve dropped a ring,â he apologised, as he climbed out.
âIt was my motherâs, and Iâd hate to lose it. I wonât
detain you a minuteâI saw where it fell.â


In less than a minute he was back in the cab with the ring.


But within that minute a crosstown car had stopped directly in front of the
cab. The cabman tried to pass to the left, but a heavy express wagon cut him
off. He tried the right, and had to back away from a furniture van that had no
business to be there. He tried to back out, but dropped his reins and swore
dutifully. He was blockaded in a tangled mess of vehicles and horses.


One of those street blockades had occurred that sometimes tie up commerce and
movement quite suddenly in the big city.


âWhy donât you drive on?â said Miss Lantry, impatiently.
âWeâll be late.â


Richard stood up in the cab and looked around. He saw a congested flood of
wagons, trucks, cabs, vans and street cars filling the vast space where
Broadway, Sixth Avenue and Thirty-fourth street cross one another as a
twenty-six inch maiden fills her twenty-two inch girdle. And still from all the
cross streets they were hurrying and rattling toward the converging point at
full speed, and hurling themselves into the struggling mass, locking wheels and
adding their driversâ imprecations to the clamour. The entire traffic of
Manhattan seemed to have jammed itself around them. The oldest New Yorker among
the thousands of spectators that lined the sidewalks had not witnessed a street
blockade of the proportions of this one.


âIâm very sorry,â said Richard, as he resumed his seat,
âbut it looks as if we are stuck. They wonât get this jumble
loosened up in an hour. It was my fault. If I hadnât dropped the ring
weââ


âLet me see the ring,â said Miss Lantry. âNow that it
canât be helped, I donât care. I think theatres are stupid,
anyway.â


At 11 oâclock that night somebody tapped lightly on Anthony
Rockwallâs door.


âCome in,â shouted Anthony, who was in a red dressing-gown, reading
a book of piratical adventures.


Somebody was Aunt Ellen, looking like a grey-haired angel that had been left on
earth by mistake.


âTheyâre engaged, Anthony,â she said, softly. âShe has
promised to marry our Richard. On their way to the theatre there was a street
blockade, and it was two hours before their cab could get out of it.


âAnd oh, brother Anthony, donât ever boast of the power of money
again. A little emblem of true loveâa little ring that symbolised
unending and unmercenary affectionâwas the cause of our Richard finding
his happiness. He dropped it in the street, and got out to recover it. And
before they could continue the blockade occurred. He spoke to his love and won
her there while the cab was hemmed in. Money is dross compared with true love,
Anthony.â


âAll right,â said old Anthony. âIâm glad the boy has
got what he wanted. I told him I wouldnât spare any expense in the matter
ifââ


âBut, brother Anthony, what good could your money have done?â


âSister,â said Anthony Rockwall. âIâve got my pirate in
a devil of a scrape. His ship has just been scuttled, and heâs too good a
judge of the value of money to let drown. I wish you would let me go on with
this chapter.â


The story should end here. I wish it would as heartily as you who read it wish
it did. But we must go to the bottom of the well for truth.


The next day a person with red hands and a blue polka-dot necktie, who called
himself Kelly, called at Anthony Rockwallâs house, and was at once
received in the library.


âWell,â said Anthony, reaching for his chequebook, âit was a
good bilinâ of soap. Letâs seeâyou had $5,000 in cash.â


âI paid out $300 more of my own,â said Kelly. âI had to go a
little above the estimate. I got the express wagons and cabs mostly for $5; but
the trucks and two-horse teams mostly raised me to $10. The motormen wanted
$10, and some of the loaded teams $20. The cops struck me hardestâ$50 I
paid two, and the rest $20 and $25. But didnât it work beautiful, Mr.
Rockwall? Iâm glad William A. Brady wasnât onto that little outdoor
vehicle mob scene. I wouldnât want William to break his heart with
jealousy. And never a rehearsal, either! The boys was on time to the fraction
of a second. It was two hours before a snake could get below Greeleyâs
statue.â


âThirteen hundredâthere you are, Kelly,â said Anthony,
tearing off a check. âYour thousand, and the $300 you were out. You
donât despise money, do you, Kelly?â


âMe?â said Kelly. âI can lick the man that invented
poverty.â


Anthony called Kelly when he was at the door.


âYou didnât notice,â said he, âanywhere in the tie-up,
a kind of a fat boy without any clothes on shooting arrows around with a bow,
did you?â


âWhy, no,â said Kelly, mystified. âI didnât. If he was
like you say, maybe the cops pinched him before I got there.â


âI thought the little rascal wouldnât be on hand,â chuckled
Anthony. âGood-by, Kelly.â
